15856007.review:
Thirteen years ago some guy was sitting at a table in a comic book convention in Tokyo trying to sell a goofy-looking short amateur visual novel he made with his little brother. Since then there's been seven more chapters of the core story, ten chapters of spin-offs and additions, ports to Nintendo DS, PS2, and PS3, a 2-on-2 fighting game, two audio drama CDs, fifty TV and ten direct-to-video episodes of anime, thirty-eight volumes of manga, seventeen books, and two live-action movies.

This is that original visual novel, with new art in an attempt to make it less goofy-looking.

There's a lot of reasons why this series blew up into a multimedia juggernaut, but it's one of my favorite stories for a simple reason: I hate it when a series tries to set up some massive, overarching mystery, but they're just making it up as they go along. Seriously, fuck you Lost and Battlestar Galactica. This is the antithesis of that. The first four chapters (of which this is the first) set up a complex, twisted mystery, then the last four chapters solve it. Everything pays off because it was all planned from the start. That guy at the table in Tokyo (who goes by the internet handle Ryukishi07) did a better job than Hollywood usually can.

The quality of this particular release is a little uneven. I liked how the old, childish art contrasted with the events and tone of the story. The new art feels too slick and maybe a little too sexy. This is a horror story about kids; it's important that they look like kids. On the other hand, at higher resolutions the old art looks like crap, and the new art isn't as bad as I originally feared from the preview images. The big disappointment is the new English translation. The old translation was clunky and had some real groaner lines, but the new translation has issues with stilted and overly literal language and some weird affectations (are they trying to make Satoko sound like a stereotypical southern belle or something? wtf?).

Overall, though, you should buy it, read it, and just put up with the stilted language and Mion's ridiculous boobtastic posture.

15854136.review:
从2012初上绿光 通过投票 到正式移植 重制立绘 翻译 到一次次内测 翻译的跑路 不断跳票 2015年 Magamgamer终于在有生之年打开了新世界的大门
[h1]关于游戏[/h1]
本作完成度还是很高的 除去之前宣称的重制立绘和英文翻译 作为跳票的补偿 加入了龙绘和日本文本
最重要的 请看标题Higurashi When They Cry Hou 在Steam上最终登陆的版本变成了奉
也就是说 有4篇出题 4篇解 3篇礼 1篇拡+1篇独占的Kamikanshi 另有一篇完全新作Hinamizawa Teiryuujyo
14篇……请大家慢慢享受有生之年系列

[h1]关于本作[/h1]
作为跳票很久的第一篇 确实开了一个好头 各方面质量都不错
前面说了 有两版立绘与双语可以选择 背景和音频依旧是原版的 没有专门请CV来做语音 有一点遗憾
卡牌系统的加入简直是狂欢 这篇的徽章是Rena系列 表情有各种武器道具和usoda的表情 背景目前来看有Rena Mion 腐竹和妹妹 稀有目前还空缺 不知道一共多少张 但是14篇都出来的话想必应有尽有

[h1]关于MOD[/h1]
这游戏结构真是简单而稳固……游戏资源并没有打包 大家可以尽情替换内容
感觉历代的画风中 PS2版本的立绘以及重制的背景 整体还是非常不错的 即便Steam版本身已经自带了真性情的龙绘 并不是所有人都能接受 新的立绘和原版画风配起来也有些奇怪 和动画也比较接近的PS2画风还是很讨喜的 鉴于游戏友好的结构 各种[url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/310360/discussions/0/620713633853108291/]MOD[/url]指日可待

[h1]关于剧情[/h1]
有些人看完本篇 觉得有些温sang暖xin人bing心kuang
当年看动画看完两篇也是觉得撑不下去了 莫名其妙地死死死

[b]MAX/MAX[/b]
[b]这是寒蝉。懂？[/b]

对于大多数熟悉龙骑士07的人来说，上面这一句话就够了吧。
For those are familiar with 07th Expansion, I think the one sentence above is enough.
那么还是为完全没有接触过寒蝉的人做一下这个系列的介(tui)绍(xiao)吧。
Here, I decide to introduce the Higurashi to the people who don't know what's Higurashi.
首先这是个充满友情与正能量的系列。注意我说的是系列，并没有在说这个独立的章节。
This is a series full of friendship and positive chapters. - I'm talking about the whole series, not the chapter Onikakushi.
相反的，这个鬼隐篇是充满了负能量的，而且非常诡异，诡异到你根本不明白为什么故事会那样发展。
YOU SHOULD KNOW THAT THIS CHAPTER IS FRIGHTFUL AND MYSTERIOUS. So mysterious that you will not know why are the all things happened.
这只是单纯的灵异恐怖小说嘛！？并不是。
Is this a simple preternatural horror fiction!? No.
鬼隐和接下来的数章中，你只会看到登场人物以各种方式走向悲惨的结局。
In Onikakushi and next several chapters, all you can do is stand beside and seeing the characters reach their dead end.
但是——请还是从鬼隐开始，一步一步走上这条漫长的道路吧。
But - please, start the endless journey from Chapter Onikakushi.
没有GE，没有NE，甚至没有任何选择。你唯一能做的就是祈祷，和看着剧中人物的挣扎。
No good endings, no normal endings, even no option to choose. All you can do... is pray, and see the characters suffering.
但是在经过这漫长的旅途，最终到达解答篇时，你却会觉得一切都感人至深。
However, after the exhausting journey and finally you arrive to the answer, everything seems to be thankful.
那样凌乱又悲惨的故事居然能有这样神妙的结局，感谢上天，感谢友情，感谢07。
How can a disordered miserable story leads to such a great ending? Thanks to god, thanks to their friendship; thanks to 07th Expansion.
坚持走完前期的惨烈吧。我想，任何人都能在最后由衷地说出一句，我能看完全部的寒蝉真是太好了。
Hold on for the sad early days. Anyone will say at last. "It's my pleasure to meet Higurashi."

PS: Switch the characters spirtes to "original" in options, and you'll see many weird faces.
正因为其质量极高的剧本，所以当年的人们才能忍受住龙骑士07这胡闹般的立绘。
People bear the weird painting technique of 07th Expansion, just because its high quality scenario.

15853121.review:
The When They Cry series consists of four story arcs each containing four "episodes".  WTC 1&2 being the question and answer arcs of Higurashi no Naku Koro ni while WTC 3&4 gives us a new mystery with Umineko no Naku Koro ni.


[b] Welcome to Hinamizawa [/b]

The first episode of When They Cry 1, Onikakushi-hen takes us to the idyllic quiet town of Hinamizawa where Keiichi (K1) has just arrived with his family to settle into a new life.   Does the usual thing, gets himself friends and starts living his new life in the countryside.  But it doesnt take long for that veneer to shatter and K1 becomes entangled in the mystery of Watanagashi Festival.

Each chapter starts of very care-free and its seemingly innocent characters are enjoying their youth.  Which makes it all the more unnerving and sometimes terrifying when everything goes to hell.  As the story goes on I found myself becoming heavily invested in it's characters and you really feel for them as the situation becomes more and more hopeless and desperate.  


[b] Welcome to Rokkenjima [/b]

Even though this is only Episode 1 of WTC1 I cannot write this and not mention Umineko no Naku Koro ni.

If Steam gets there, it will take us to a new setting with new characters although the world of Umineko & Higurashi do seem connected.  WTC3 Episode 1 takes us to the island of Rokkenjima where Battler, who belongs to the wealthy Ushiromiya family, has just returned for the first time in six years to attend a family conference.  But the island and its inhabitants lie heavily under the influence of the witch Beatrice.

Umineko feels a bit different to Higurashi as things are a bit more fantastical, but personally I found it to be more compelling and I am still invested in its characters and story.  I hope the complete mystery comes out on steam but that may be unlikely as only Higurashi was translated and published by MangaGamer and Umineko never got the the love.  But you can get fansubs at [url=http://witch-hunt.com] Witch Hunt [/url] and a mod to play with PS3 Graphics at  [url=http://uminekofix.wikia.com/wiki/Tweaking_Umineko_Wiki] UminekoFix [/url]


In summary.  When They Cry is not like any other Visual Novel out there and it may be more correct to refer to it as a Sound Novel as 07th Expansion do.  Both Higurashi and Umineko have a great soundtrack which is basically what this is all about (Sound Novel being the hint).  There are no choices,  you just follow the story and try to work out the mystery.   Lots of scary moments, lots of intrigue and lots and lots of feels.

The community back in the day was awesome and had many competing theories and there was countless doujins and fan arts that kept you going while we all waited for the next episode to be released.  I hope that can return for a new load of fans on steam.

15852221.review:
i've been a fan of the when they cry series for a long while and was really hyped about the game coming to steam, but upon playing i can't say i'd recommend this port of the game to anyone. 

first of all, the english translation is really awkward and really, really unnecessarily complicated. it's like a chore to get through the text because of all the odd sentence structures and the narration feels out of character for keiichi (what high school dude uses the word 'accompaniment', seriously). the way the Very Obviously Japanese characters talked about receiving their allowance in dollars was more than a bit odd too

as for things other than the language, the character sprites have some easily fixable anatomy mistakes that bother me personally, but aren't too obvious if you try not to pay too much attention to them (i suppose). maybe it's due to being used to used to different sprite sets but the models in this port specifically look kind of off...

the option to change languages from english to japanese & from the new sprites to the original ones was nice enough, but overall it doesn't feel like this steam edition brings anything new to the game (other than trading cards and achievements)

i bought this to support 7th expansion's fantastic visual novel work, but i'm not sure if i'll be getting the next chapters, if only because of the because of the bad port

i'd only recommend getting this version if you're new to the series and have no means of getting a different edition with better sprite and translation patches. other than that, don't bother

15850373.review:
To start off, Higurashi is a kinetic novel. That means that there is no gameplay, the entire thing is just a bunch of text, with pictures of characters and the background to help illustrate it, topped off with sound effects. If you hate reading, kinetic/visual novels are not for you. 

Higurashi has a total of 8 main chapters. This is only the first one. The rest are slowing going through the translation process. Some chapters relate to others, so if this is your first experience with Higurashi, I'd almost recommend for you to wait until all 8 are released before you read them all so you won't forget some of the details. 

Higurashi is a horror/mystery. The protagonist moves to rural Japan from the city and is adapting to his new life in a town where the population is so small that his school consists of one classroom with students in many different grades. He befriends four of them and they do a bunch of things kids do, but slowly the protagonists hears more and more disturbing rumors about his new village. As if to heighten his fears and paranoia, eventually, people start dying.

Having read my fair share of Christie and Doyle, I will say that the mystery in Higurashi is top notch. While it's not your typical closed circle murder mystery (which is the theme of the author's second work, Umineko), the author does leave just enough clues here and there for intelligent readers to figure out the truth behind the events in Higurashi. If you're like me and couldn't figure it out despite all the hints, that's ok too. The last few chapters act as an "answer key" and reveals the truth for you. 

TL;DR: if you enjoy reading mysteries, Higurashi is definitely for you, though I may recommend waiting till all 8 main chapters are translated.

15849712.review:
A must-read for any mystery fans and visual novel fans out there. Higurashi is a top-notch mystery horror visual novel with very memorable characters and a story that keeps you guessing and thinking. Let yourself get immersed as much as possible, and it will be an awesome experience.

Keep in mind that this is only the first chapter out of eight (for the main story). The rest will be released later on. But even just this first chapter is easily enough to get you hooked for now. And for that price? Yea, worth it.

Also, this is a remastered version of the original visual novel, with some new options, a new translation, new sprite art, etc. So even those of us who have already read the original can get plenty of enjoyment out of this one.

Watched the anime? Still worth it, I can assure you. It's a different experience to read it in visual novel format. It provides more details on everything and the creepy/paranoia-inducing atmosphere is much more prevalent in the visual novel compared to the anime. In general, scenes tend to be more effective and powerful in this, and it feels more mysterious. Plus, in my opinion, the characters are better shown in the visual novel as well.

Are you a fan of:
- Mystery novels?
- Dark stores?
- Cute anime girls?
- Atmospheric tone via sound?

Then this game is probably for you. An intriguing story based in 1980s Rural japan, and for a super cheap price. Even if you aren't into anime/japan stuff, this is still a must-have for anyone who enjoys mystery as a genre. To the outside viewer, it may seem like a cheap, dated visual novel, with a boring introduction and a somewhat strange setting, but the storytelling in this game makes it hold its own, and probably will for years and years to come. The only downside I can find of this release is the dated, dated music. It's the music from the original game, released in 2002. It might turn off some people at first, but hopefully you'll be able to get past that.

15849474.review:
Finally, a legitimate and reworked version of the Higurashi no Naku Koro ni series. These visual novels are certainly the best of the mystery horror genre and will remain a classic in the hearts of many. The work itself is a masterpiece, written by Ryukishi07 of 07th Expansion back in 2002, and still retains the feeling that it did all those years ago. Don't hesitate on this one if you thought about it for even a second. 

Chances are you have watched or heard of the anime series known as Higurashi no Naku Koro ni if you're looking at this game right now. This game is the origin of the anime, but with updated art and so forth. Be warned, this is no ordinary game. This work is a piece of art filled with hours of paranoia, second guessing, and overall mystery. If you have ever once philosophized to yourself asking what life is about, maybe you will find your answers here.

I am glad that the series has finally come to our shores remastered so that everyone I know can understand why this series is something so dear to me. If you like mystery, horror, or even if you've already seen the anime, I can assure you that your time will be well spent here. Please, take a look inside of one of the most mind-boggling and revolutionary novels to have ever been created.

15847361.review:
Higurashi no Naku Koro Ni or Higurashi: When They Cry is one of the most famous horror anime series ever for good reason. A lot of mystery solving, blood and gore, and yandere. Although originally a visual novel and this being the Steam remake, the Higurashi series is widely known in the anime fan culture, and even on the internet due to some memes being born from it, as well as many scenes of the anime being uploaded on YouTube. The games in the series have been released on PC, PS2, PS3, PS Vita, iOS, Android, and Nintendo DS, as well as the popular anime adaptation and the manga adaptations. I first discovered Higurashi from the clips on YouTube and it has been one of my favorite franchises ever since. This particular arc, Onikakushi-hen is one of my favorites because I own the manga adaptation of it. I have also played [spoiler]Watanagashi-hen and Meakashi-hen.[/spoiler] 

The gameplay of a visual novel game is pretty basic. You click and read the text that's on the screen. Pretty simple, huh? Well, Higurashi is a different case. The story follows the myth of [spoiler] Oyashiro-sama's Curse,[/spoiler] a myth that is linked to consecutive murders that occur every summer in the town of Hinamizawa. With every murder, another person goes missing. Every story arc is like the movie Groundhog Day as you are stuck in a time-loop. There are 4 main Question arcs, and 4 Answer arcs, and many other extra arcs that go deeper into the story. You play the role of [spoiler]Keiichi Maebara,[/spoiler] who recently moves to Hinamizawa. Every story arc is different because in every arc, a different character falls victim to [spoiler]The Hinamizawa Syndrome,[/spoiler] which causes the character to act in strange and violent ways. By reading the story and reading tips that you can unlock, you start to figure out what's going on, who's responsible for the strange acts, and the murders of some of the main characters. The only one who can solve the mystery of Hinamizawa and the "Curse," is you, the player.

I suck at writing reviews, but I highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a good mystery to solve, anyone who wants to familiarize themselves with the Higurashi franchise, or anyone who loves the series and has been a longtime fan of it.

"Higurashi When They Cry: Onikakushi" หรือที่มีชื่อแบบไทย ๆ ว่า "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง: บทยักษ์ลักพา" ก็คือ Visual Novel ที่ถูกวางจำหน่ายเป็นครั้งแรกตั้งแต่ปี 2002 หรือก็คือเมื่อกว่าหนึ่งทศวรรษมาแล้ว ซึ่ง "Higurashi When They Cry Hou - Ch.1 Onikakushi" ที่เราเห็นกันอยู่นี้ก็คือ Visual Novel ตัวเดียวกันกับที่เคยวางจำหน่ายเมื่อตอน 2002 นั่นล่ะ เพียงแต่ถูกหยิบนำมาปรับแต่งรูปร่างหน้าตาเสียใหม่ให้แลดูน่ารักน่าเอ็นดูขึ้นและมี text เป็นภาษาอังกฤษเพียงเท่านั้น ไม่ได้มีการเติมเสียงหรือ Cut-scene เพิ่มเติมแต่อย่างใด ดังนั้นถ้าคุณเคยได้ครองครองตัวเกมในเวอร์ชั่นอื่น ๆ เช่น Matsuri หรือ Sui มาก่อนและไม่อยากที่จะเก็บสะสมไว้เป็นของดูต่างหน้า ตัวผมเองนั้นก็ไม่แนะนำยกเว้นแต่เมื่อมันลดราคา

ว่าแต่ "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง" เป็นเรื่องราวเกี่ยวกับอะไรล่ะ?

สำหรับผู้ที่ไม่คุ้นเคยกับซีรีย์นี้ ในแวบแรกที่คุณเห็น คุณก็อาจจะคิดว่ามันเป็น Visual Novel ที่เน้นขายตัวละครสุดโมเอ้ที่แสนจะธรรมดาสามัญ ซึ่งถ้าคุณกำลังคิดเช่นนี้อยู่ ผมก็ขอบอกเลยว่าคุณคิดผิดมหันต์ เพราะ Visual Novel นั้นจะบอกเล่าเรื่องราวของเด็กหนุ่มที่ชื่อ "มาเอบาระ เคอิจิ" ที่ได้ย้ายบ้านไปยังหมู่บ้านกลางป่าเขาอันสุดแสนจะกันดารและได้มีส่วนเข้าไปพัวพันกับเหตุการณ์นองเลือดที่วนเวียนติดลูปกลับมาซ้ำไปซ้ำมาไม่รู้จบ อย่าให้ตัวละครสุดโมเอ้ของเกมหลอกคุณได้ เพราะ "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง" ก็คือหนึ่งใน Visual Novel ที่นองเลือดที่สุดเรื่องหนึ่งเท่าที่เคยมีมา ดังนั้นถ้าคุณไม่ค่อยจะถูกโฉลกกับ Visual Novel เลือดสาดที่มีจุดหักมุมชวนสลด ผมก็ไม่แนะนำให้ตามซีรีย์นี้ครับ แต่ถ้าคุณเป็นคนที่ชอบเรื่องราวแนวลี้ลับอยู่แล้ว "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง" ก็คือหนึ่งใน Visual Novel ที่ส่วนตัวผมเองอยากแนะนำให้คุณได้ลองสัมผัสสักครั้ง

คะแนน 6 / 10

ข้อดี
+ ตัวละครถูกเขียนขึ้นใหม่ทั้งหมดซึ่งต้องกล่าวว่าดูดีกว่าต้นฉบับ "มาก"
+ เนื้อหาสะเทือนขวัญสุดล้ำที่ไม่เหมือนใครและยังคงไม่มีใครเหมือน

ข้อเสีย
- มันคือ Visual Novel ในเวอร์ชั่น 2002 ที่เปลี่ยนไปเพียงแค่ตัวละครที่ดูดีขึ้นเท่านั้น (แน่นอนว่าตัวเกมเป็น Visual Novel ที่เป็นตัวหนังสือและภาพเน้น ๆ ไม่มีเสียงประกอบ ดังนั้นถ้าคุณไม่ใช่คนที่มีใจรักการอ่านสักเท่าไหร่ ผมก็ไม่แนะนำ)
- ความละเอียดสูงสุดของหน้าจอยังคงเป็น 1024 X 768 เช่นเคย ถึงแม้จะปรับเต็มหน้าจอได้ก็ตามทีเถอะ

สรุป
+ ถ้าคุณไม่เคยได้สัมผัสกับ "ยามเมื่อเหล่าจักจั่นกรีดร้อง" มาก่อนเลยไม่ว่าจะทั้งทาง Visual Novel, อนิเมะ หรือมังงะ และอยากรู้ว่ามันเทพอย่างไร แนะนำให้กดเลยไม่ผิดหวังแน่นอน (ถ้าคุณสามารถอ่านได้จนจบ) แต่ถ้าคุณเคยได้สัมผัสกับตัวมังงะหรืออนิเมะมาก่อนและไม่ใช่แฟนบอยของซีรีย์นี้ จะรอก่อนจนถึงเมื่อมันลดราคาก็ไม่ถือว่าสายนะ (ส่วนในกรณีของแฟนบอย ผมคิดว่าคุณคงกดไปแล้วก่อนที่จะได้อ่าน Review ผมด้วยซ้ำ ดังนั้นคงไม่จำเป็นต้องเอ่ยถึงล่ะนะ)

15846959.review:
*Note: This is both a (spoiler free) review of the game with some comments about the whole series that will be released chapter by chapter as they are retranslated*

As a huge When They Cry fan I'm glad to see it appear on Steam and hopefully gain the attention it deserves. That it comes with a completely revamped translation (as MangaGamers old translation was filled with bad grammar and formating) and new sprites is just icing on the cake.

Story: Since Higurashi is a Sound novel the story has to be the most important part of the game and it does that magnificently. While the first hour or so of the game is rather slow it then quickly opens up and becomes one of the most paranoia- and horror-filled experiences I have ever read (perhaps only eclipsed by the first arc of it's spiritual sequel, Umineko no Naku Koro Ni). But a note for those who are used to flag based Visual novels where there are occasionally dialogue options that often effect what happens next and what ending you will receive, Higurashi does not contain any choices. Higurashi is instead what is called a kinetic mystery novel where you, as the player, are supposed to read the story and through the hints provided in this chapter and the the other chapters in the so called questions arc (ch. 1-4 with 5-8 being called the answer arc) try to solve the mystery. So, don't expect any choices but instead, pick up a pen and paper, fire up your brain and try to solve this strange case.

Characters: Characters have always been the greatest part of Ryukushi's writing and the characters in the Higurashi is no exception. While, in the beginning, the characters look like normal people if slightly strange and eccentric, as the story moves forward you will get a whole new view of them as the darker parts of their backstories and natures are revealed. And while there are many side characters that doesn't get that much development (or even a sprite) almost everyone else receives at least one chocking reveal and many of the villains are also shown to have at least one sympathetic side to them.

Art: In many Visual novels the art is usualy ranging from decent to fantastic, When They Cry usually put itself on the lower part of the curve. The background is just real photographs (taken in the Japanese village Shirakawa-go) with a photoshop filter and the original sprites are very crude. But in my opinion that doesn't really matter as the main focus is the story, and the characters are mostly there to help you get forward, make you care about them, and in a few cases give out a few laughs with how they look. But as I said above this re-release comes with new character-sprites which the MangaGamer team worked on in coordination with 07th Expansion. I think they look really good and captures the original quite well but on the other hand they do contrast a bit against the background and sadly aren't are expressive as the original sprites (compare Rena's new shocked/embarrased sprites with the originals).

Music: As the name Sound novel implies the music is one of the primary aspects of the game. But while the music in this re-release is better then the one used in the original release (as MG couldn't get permission to use it) it is still rather weak compared to the series from ch. 4 and onward. But that doesn't mean it's bad, it's just not as good as it is later on. The music often fits perfectly with the scenes and the scary scenes are often made even worse by showing that silence is often even more scary than a scare chord, by removing the music during those scenes.

Gameplay: As I noted earlier, there is no gameplay at all in this ''game''. The closest is that after every few chapters a couple of TIPS are opened that you can read. But while you can skip them it is strongly suggested that you read them as they are side stories that are either background material, cryptic discussions or contains further hints to the mystery.

Final thoughts: Of all the stories I have ever read, When They Cry is probably my all time number one and while I consider Umineko to be slightly better, Higurashi is still really good. So if you either want to try out what a Visual novel actually is or just want a good and engaging mystery story with well written characters and a amazing soundtrack in a new and interesting format, pick up this game.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You are invited to solve this strange case. Will you pick up the challenge or will you give up and leave it unsolved. And if you do pick it up will you succeed to find the truth or will you fail like so many others?

Welcome to Hinamizawa.

15846237.review:
I'm not really good at writing reviews, but I figured I'd give it a shot since this is a series I'm pretty in love with.

Onikakushi ("Spirited Away by the Demon" if I recall correctly) is the first of 8 "core" arcs in the [i]Higurashi no naku koro ni[/i] series. It was first released in 2002 as a visual novel but most here in the west are probably more familiar with the Studio Deen anime series that was an adaptation of the series. Despite the cutesy sprite art and generally energetic feel that dominates most of the work, it is solidly a mystery and thriller- or suspense-type visual novel.

This is a straight port and slight remaster of that original visual novel. It is very much a [i]novel[/i] and essentially reads like one, with time to read depending on how fast you can read. I read through the arcs, which took around 5 - 8 hours per arc. There are no choices, no voice acting, and no branching storyline. There's also no gore to be found here, so if you are squeamish or have heard about the series' reputation, don't let that dissuade you.

Unlike MangaGamer's previous version of this, the original music was restored, and additionally, more "traditionally animesque" sprites were added as an alternative to Ryukishi07's (the author). The translation, also, has also been improved quite a lot from what I remember of the previous version.

I think 6$ is a fair price for what it is, a solid visual novel, and at the same price as the crappy iOS port you get a much  better product.

15846160.review:
Owning the complete series of the manga, the iPod version of this game and having already watched all of the episodes of the anime, I always love to come back to this touching story.

The story plays with you, manipulates you into thinking things that are not really how they seem, and not in a cheap way.
It is very well thought-through, and the characters are pretty unique and just lovable.

It is incredible how many twists it has. Every time I started the series anew, I caught some new details that explained a little more about the mystery in this world.

If you like reading mystery/thrillers/dramas and can slip your mind into that world, this is for you.

You're put in the shoes of the main character (Maebara Keiichi) and your shown how he reacts to the horrors of creepy girls, needles and demons. 15845715.review:
In both its visual novel and anime incarnations, Higurashi When They Cry, also known as Higurashi no Naku Koro ni, is revered as one of the greatest horror/mystery works of their mediums.

---

[h1]If I liked the anime, will I like the visual novel?[/h1]

Definitely, without question. The anime is a great adaptation in two ways. First, it does not cut out or distort many important plot points, although there are certainly changes. Second, it makes fantastic use of the advantages of the animated medium to create suspense.

The visual novel, however, explains several key plot points better than the anime does. Most importantly, the visual novel portrays paranoia and confusion far better than anime ever could. The visual novel really gets you thinking like the protagonist thinks, whereas the anime just has you experiencing what the protagonist experiences.

Chapter 1, Onikakushi, covers the first four episodes of the anime.

---

Two main things set Higurashi apart from otherwise similar horror titles.

[h1]Slice of Life Camaraderie[/h1]

Higurashi in its entirety isn't just a story about how bad things happen and a bunch of people die. At its core, it is a story about overcoming adversity (although the first chapter is very much about bad things happening).

Higurashi's early slice of life scenes reinforce this overarching positive theme. They depict a group of friends who participate in cutthroat competitions on a daily basis. They struggle and play dirty to improve themselves and each other. It's very much [b]not[/b] your usual slice of life.

[h1]Paranoia[/h1]

Paranoia plays a huge role in the first few chapters of Higurashi. Many characters deeply involved in the series of murders have yet to be revealed. Two main characters have yet to be introduced. The protagonist, and by extension the reader, doesn't know why or even [b]what[/b] is happening. In this way, Higurashi is quite similar to the visual novel Chaos;Head (excuse me, ChäoS;HEAd). An unreliable protagonist tries to survive and figure out what the hell is going on.

You could say that Higurashi is to horror visual novels as Amnesia: The Dark Descent is to horror video games.

---

Higurashi is [b]phenomenal[/b] bang for your buck in terms of both quality and quantity. It is very much enjoyable as a standalone work, but also leads into a greater overarching story. What are you waiting for?
